title: RL34114
content: Congress's contempt power is used to respond to acts that obstruct the legislative process, such as a witness refusing to comply with a congressional subpoena. Congress has three formal methods to combat noncompliance, including the authority to detain and imprison a contemnor until they comply. Congress has three formal methods to combat noncompliance with a subpoena: inherent contempt power allows Congress to detain and imprison a contemnor until compliance, criminal contempt permits certification for prosecution, and serves as punishment without necessarily encouraging compliance. The contempt statute allows Congress to certify a contempt citation for criminal prosecution of the contemnor who fails to comply with a congressional subpoena. Criminal contempt serves as punishment but may not lead to compliance. Congress can also seek civil enforcement through the judicial branch to ensure compliance with subpoenas, especially for executive branch officials. The report discusses Congress's contempt power and enforcement of subpoenas, including legal obligations, contempt of court consequences, civil enforcement for executive branch officials, and obstacles in enforcing contempt actions.
